Your dog knows certain words ‚Äî I‚Äôve been around dogs that have learned to spell W-A-L-K ‚Äî but it doesn‚Äôt actually speak the same language as you. But dogs are smart. Only songwriters need to worry about the tempo of their words, right? Wrong. Your marketing words need to change tempo to keep readers interested. How? By switching up your sentence and paragraph length. If every piece of content you publish has three-sentence paragraphs your audience is yawning and scrolling on by. When we read, we keep a beat. By using fewer or more words, it changes the pace of your reading. 1-3 word sentences make a bigger impact. They're short, sharp statements or questions designed to grab attention. Longer sentences are for informing or weaving a story. Our eyes and minds get tired from reading, so looking at a screen or page where every paragraph goes from border to border is hard work. Let your readers catch their breath by adding full stops and switching up the sentence length. It ain't hard. But it's darn effective.

‚ÄúI believe the road to hell is paved with adverbs‚Äù Yes, it‚Äôs polarizing, but there‚Äôs truth in it. Even though there are also exceptions. What did Stephen King mean by this? ‚ùå Beginner writers tend to pack as much as possible into one sentence, hoping it will evoke some kind of feeling or reaction. ‚úÖ Experienced writers avoid adverbs and adjectives because they‚Äôre less forceful than nouns and verbs. But the problem isn‚Äôt the adverb itself. It‚Äôs the meaningless adverbs that are‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ meaningless. For example: ‚Ä¢ Very ‚Ä¢ Truly ‚Ä¢ Really ‚Ä¢ Extremely They don‚Äôt add any new information or meaning to a sentence. For example: ‚ÄúShe was extremely happy‚Äù vs ‚ÄúShe was happy‚Äù Either you‚Äôre happy, or you‚Äôre not. If you want to describe how happy she was, you can use more specific words such as delighted, elated, euphoric, etc. ‚ÄúOkay, Joe. So you‚Äôre telling me adverbs suck? Don‚Äôt use them?‚Äù Not exactly. Let‚Äôs look at an example where adverbs DO add value. (1) To change the meaning: In the ad below, the introductory line, ‚ÄúHonestly now,‚Äù can be removed. But it would change the way you read the sentence in your head. It would have a different tone. Version without adverb: ‚ÄúDid you spend your youth dreaming about someday owning a Nissan or a Mitsubishi?‚Äù That feels more like an interrogation. It‚Äôs factual. vs. Version with adverb: ‚ÄúHonestly now, did you spend your youth dreaming about someday owning a Nissan or a Mitsubishi?‚Äù This version is friendlier. It focuses more on the unspoken truth ‚Äî that you‚Äôre kidding yourself if you don‚Äôt want a fancy car. --- P.S. If you enjoyed this, I wrote more about when you should use adverbs in your copy here: https://lnkd.in/eQqcNG-Y

That phrase "I don't know who needs to hear this"? It's played out. It's a song on repeat, the vibe is gone. So, how do you craft fresh hooks? Here's the scoop: -Know your audience. Understand their dreams, fears, and passions. Use this knowledge to craft a hook that hits. -Stay original. Avoid clich√©s and overused phrases. Let your unique vibe shine and write in your voice. Ignite their curiosity. A great hook sparks interest. It's like whispering a secret. They'll want to lean in to hear more. Listen, a hook is like a movie trailer. The answer is MORE of you. What is the question? The question is: How can you make this better? And how can you improve what you are doing? On the weekend I was rewriting an article based on feedback from the editor. This was a really fun feature ‚Äî I had visited coffee roasters, chocolatiers and tea stores all over Vancouver and was writing about them. Somehow my words became very clinical, "marketing-y" instead of conveying my experience of each visit. I had hidden myself, and the result was kinda generic. The answer (MORE of you) applies to so many things: from facilitating a group meeting to creating a brand for your new company, and obviously to writing compelling content, whether it's editorial or marketing or somewhere in between. But the problem is, it is HARD to put yourself into everything. And in an influencer-saturated market, cutting through the noise to find the right dose of you has become an art. The other problem is that we are not all extroverts so that "more of me" energy can be hard to harness. For me, feedback from my editor was a reminder of what I had in myself. And it surprised me, because, when I'm working with others, as an editor or a coach, I'm doing exactly that, showing people where they can bring MORE of themselves to the story... it's a lot easier to look at what someone is doing and see where they can make it shine. If you're stuck this week, remember where you can find the answer. Here I am at Van Cha Teahouse in Vancouver for the above-mentioned assignment which, sadly, you won't get the chance to read as proof of my re-write since it will be published in Dutch ;)
